pages.text:
Marin County EMS Constituents
Benita McLarin, FACHE
From: Dustin Ballard, MD; Medical Director
DIRECTOR
Marin County EMS Agency
Matt Willis, MD
CHRIS LE BAUDOUR
EMS ADMINISTRATOR Public Health Officer, Marin Health & Human Services
Date: May 1, 2021
Emergency Medical Services
1600 Los Gamos Drive
Suite 220 Re: Memorandum: Fentanyl and Analogs
San Rafael, CA 94903
415 473 6871 T
There has a been a recent surge in opioid overdose deaths in Marin County that
415 473 3747 F
are partially attributable to fentanyl and its analogs (such as carfentanil). In
415 473 3344 TTY
California, fentanyl and its analogs have also been found in samples of other
www.marinEMS.org
drugs including heroin, methamphetamine, cocaine, and counterfeit pills made
to look like prescription medications such as alprazolam (Xanax).
Such illicit drugs may pose as a contact hazard to law enforcement and other
first responders and while we are not aware of any symptomatic first responder
exposures in this county, we are taking this opportunity to remind first
responders of scene safety principles.
We are committed to ensuring the safety of our first responders and are
addressing the fentanyl hazard in multiple ways -- including close monitoring of
opioid overdoses in the county, educational programs to Emergency Medical
Services and first responders as well as ongoing distribution of intranasal
naloxone (Narcan) to law enforcement and other agencies.
There is limited data to guide personal protective equipment (PPE)
recommendations as fentanyl and its analogs do not have established
occupational exposure limits. First responder hazard is almost certainly greater
with inhalation of powder rather than contact via the skin.
We continue to recommend that first responder agencies follow the CDC
guidelines on PPE and, as they suggest, assess the need and level of PPE on a
case by case basis: https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/fentanyl/risk.html
